author: Sara Randazzo
title: M&A Litigator Sandra Goldstein Leaves Cravath for Kirkland & Ellis
text:
0 COMMENTS Sandra Goldstein, a New York litigator at the center of major M&A deals, is taking her practice from longtime home Cravath, Swaine & Moore LLP to Kirkland & Ellis LLP, according to a person familiar with the matter.
The move is the latest example of partners leaving Wall Street law firms that operate on a lockstep pay system to firms willing to lure stars with top dollars.
Ms. Goldstein, 53, has represented companies including Barnes & Noble Inc., IBM Corp. , J. Crew Group Inc., Qualcomm Inc. and Xerox Corp. She is often hired to advise companies facing litigation over mergers and acquisitions, as well as in securities actions, governance-related disputes and commercial lawsuits.
She’s currently representing Williams Co s. in litigation over a failed merger with rival pipeline operator Energy Transfer Equity LP. A Delaware judge ruled in 2016 that ETE could back out of its merger agreement with Williams Cos., and now the companies are in a dispute over a related breakup fee Williams says it is owed.
Ms. Goldstein, who started at Kirkland on Friday, also represented Barnes & Noble in a successful court battle in 2010 to uphold the company’s creation of a “poison pill” that prevented outside investors from acquiring 20% or more of the bookseller’s shares.
Cravath, among the most elite law firms in the country, is one of few remaining that continue to pay partners according to seniority rather than how much work they bring in. Proponents say such a lockstep system fosters collegiality, but it faces challenges in a legal market now built more around star partners that control large books of business.
Kirkland has hired two other Cravath partners in recent years. Cravath in 2016 also lost M&A partner Scott Barshay to Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP
Ms. Goldstein joined Cravath in 1987 and in 1994 became the youngest partner ever at age 30.
Ms. Goldstein led Cravath’s litigation department from 2010 until 2016, around the time that deal lawyer Faiza Saeed took over as presiding partner of the firm from Allen Parker, now general counsel at Wells Fargo & Co .
